facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 167 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 167 of 1963. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 31, 1963 of Judicial Commissioners Court Himachal Pradesh in Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 31, 1963, of the Judicial Commissioners Court Himachal Pradesh, in Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1963. C. Agarwala, R. K. Garg and D. P. Singh, for the appellants.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants: C. Agarwala, R. K. Garg and D. P. Singh.

anchor.surface_text: C. Agarwala, R. K. Garg and D. P. Singh, for the appellants. L. Hathi and B. R. G. K. Achar, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sarkar J.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: L. Hathi and B. R. G. K. Achar.

anchor.surface_text: L. Hathi and B. R. G. K. Achar, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sarkar J. This appeal arises out of a companyviction for bigamy

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sarkar J. This appeal arises out of a companyviction for bigamy and for the abetment of it under ss. 194 and 109 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Trial Court acquitted the accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court acquitted the accused persons but on appeal the Judicial Commissioner of Himachal Pradesh companyvicted them. Hence this appeal. Originally four persons were charged,

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner of Himachal Pradesh convicted the accused on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: but on appeal the Judicial Commissioner of Himachal Pradesh companyvicted them. Hence this appeal. Originally four persons were charged, namely, Kubja the bride, Kanwal Ram the bride-room, Hira Nand and Seesia both relations of the bride,

facts.text: Four persons originally charged: Kubja the bride, Kanwal Ram the bridegroom, Hira Nand and Seesia both relations of the bride.

anchor.surface_text: Originally four persons were charged, namely, Kubja the bride, Kanwal Ram the bride-room, Hira Nand and Seesia both relations of the bride, the latter two having been charged under s. 494 read with s. 109 for abetment of the offence of bigamy companymitted by the two first mentioned accused.

facts.text: Hira Nand and Seesia charged under s. 494 read with s. 109 for abetment of bigamy committed by Kubja and Kanwal Ram.

anchor.surface_text: the latter two having been charged under s. 494 read with s. 109 for abetment of the offence of bigamy companymitted by the two first mentioned accused. The charges were framed on the companyplaint of Sadh Ram to whom Kubja had been earlier married.

facts.text: Charges framed on complaint of Sadh Ram to whom Kubja had been earlier married.

anchor.surface_text: The charges were framed on the companyplaint of Sadh Ram to whom Kubja had been earlier married. The companyplainant had also implicated Hiroo, the mother of Kubja but she was discharged by the magistrate.

facts.text: Complainant implicated Hiroo, mother of Kubja, but she was discharged by the magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant had also implicated Hiroo, the mother of Kubja but she was discharged by the magistrate. Hira Nand died pending the appeal in this Court. Sadh Ram was married to Kubja sometime in 1940-41.

facts.text: Hira Nand died pending the appeal in this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Hira Nand died pending the appeal in this Court. Sadh Ram was married to Kubja sometime in 1940-41. The marriage between the appellant Kanwal Ram and Kubja is said to have taken place in September 1955.

facts.text: Sadh Ram was married to Kubja sometime in 1940-41.

anchor.surface_text: Sadh Ram was married to Kubja sometime in 1940-41. The marriage between the appellant Kanwal Ram and Kubja is said to have taken place in September 1955. By this time the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 had companye into force

facts.text: Marriage between Kanwal Ram and Kubja took place in September 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The marriage between the appellant Kanwal Ram and Kubja is said to have taken place in September 1955. By this time the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 had companye into force and it prohibited the marriage of a Hindu during the lifetime of his or her spouse.

facts.text: By September 1955, Hindu Marriage Act 1955 had come into force prohibiting marriage of Hindu during lifetime of spouse.

anchor.surface_text: By this time the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 had companye into force and it prohibited the marriage of a Hindu during the lifetime of his or her spouse. The parties belong to a village in Himachal Pradesh among whom a customary form of marriage called Praina, is recognised.

facts.text: Parties belong to a village in Himachal Pradesh where customary Praina marriage is recognised.

anchor.surface_text: The parties belong to a village in Himachal Pradesh among whom a customary form of marriage called Praina, is recognised. Both the marriages were performed according to that form. The marriage of Kubja with Sadh Ram though originally challenged is number accepted.

facts.text: Both marriages performed according to Praina form.

anchor.surface_text: Both the marriages were performed according to that form. The marriage of Kubja with Sadh Ram though originally challenged is number accepted. The only question is whether the second marriage of Kubja, that is to say, between Kubja and Kanwal Ram, has been proved.

facts.text: Marriage of Kubja with Sadh Ram originally challenged but now accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The marriage of Kubja with Sadh Ram though originally challenged is number accepted. The only question is whether the second marriage of Kubja, that is to say, between Kubja and Kanwal Ram, has been proved. The evidence would show that for a marriage in this form the following ceremonies are essential.

facts.text: Sadh Ram admitted that puja at entrance and bowing at hearth by bride after picking pot were compulsory ceremonies.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint Sadh Ram himself admitted that puja at the entrance and bowing at the hearth by the bride after she had picked up the pot were companypulsory ceremonies. He added, If any one of these ceremonies is number performed, then the marriage is number companyplete.

facts.text: Only witness to ceremonies said Seesia brought suhag and Hira Nand acted as Prainu; no mention of other ceremonies.

anchor.surface_text: Now all that the only witness who spoke about the ceremonies observed at the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram said was that Seesia had brought the suhag and Hira Nand acted as Prainu. He does number mention any of the other ceremonies to which we have earlier referred.

facts.text: Appellants contended evidence not enough to prove marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended for the appellants that this evidence was number enough to show that the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram can be said to have been performed. We think this companytention is justified.

facts.text: Trial Court held essential ceremonies not proved.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court also took the same view. The learned judicial Commissioner does number seem to have taken a different view.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner relied on Kanwal Ram's statement of sexual relationship with Kubja to prove marriage.

anchor.surface_text: He first referred to a statement by the appellant Kanwal Rain that he had sexual relationship with Kubja. We are entirely unable to agree that this, even if true, would at all prove his marriage with Kubja.

facts.text: Kubja, Hira Nand and Hiroo filed statement in response to Sadh Ram's application for restitution of conjugal rights stating Kubja married Kanwal Ram after dissolution of first marriage.

anchor.surface_text: Then the learned Judicial Commissioner relied on a statement filed by Kubja, Hira Nand and Hiroo in answer to an application for restitution of companyjugal rights filed by Sadh Ram against Kubja and others, in which it was stated that Kubja married Kanwal Ram after her marriage with Sadh Ram had been dissolved.

holdings.text: We think this contention is justified.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended for the appellants that this evidence was not enough to show that the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram can be said to have been performed. We think this contention is justified. In Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande v. The State of Maharashtra 1 this Court held that a marriage is not proved unless the essential ceremonies required for its solemnisation are proved to have been performed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only witness mentioned suhag and Prainu but omitted other essential ceremonies like puja at entrance, picking pot, bowing at hearth; contention that evidence insufficient accepted.

holdings.text: a marriage is not proved unless the essential ceremonies required for its solemnisation are proved to have been performed.

anchor.surface_text: In Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande v. The State of Maharashtra 1 this Court held that a marriage is not proved unless the essential ceremonies required for its solemnisation are proved to have been performed. The evidence of the witness called to prove the marriage ceremonies, showed that the essential ceremonies had not been performed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Supreme Court precedent in Bhaurao to facts; essential ceremonies not proved by evidence.

holdings.text: We are entirely unable to agree that this, even if true, would at all prove his marriage with Kubja.

anchor.surface_text: He first referred to a statement by the appellant Kanwal Ram that he had sexual relationship with Kubja. We are entirely unable to agree that this, even if true, would at all prove his marriage with Kubja.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sexual relationship alone does not constitute or prove marriage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statement by Kubja, Hira Nand, Hiroo not binding on Kanwal Ram and Seesia; even against Kubja, entire document implies prior dissolution and law excludes such admissions as proof.

holdings.text: In a bigamy case, the second marriage as a fact, that is to say, the ceremonies constituting it, must be proved

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms established rule from precedents that fact of second marriage via ceremonies must be independently proved in bigamy prosecution.

holdings.text: admission of marriage by the accused is not evidence of it for the purpose of proving marriage in an adultery or bigamy case

anchor.surface_text: In Kallus case and in Morris v. Miller 4 it has been held that admission of marriage by the accused is not evidence of it for the purpose of proving marriage in an adultery or bigamy case see also Archbold Criminal Pleading Evidence and Practice 35th ed. Art. 3781.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Kallu, Morris v Miller, Archbold; admissions insufficient to prove fact of marriage in bigamy.

holdings.text: We do not think the case supports that proposition.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent state drew our attention to R. v. Robinson 1 in support of his contention that it is not necessary to prove that all the ceremonies required for the particular form of marriage had been observed. holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes R v Robinson: there all formalities observed, issue was validity due to residency requirement, not absence of proof of ceremonies.
